answer_html: \(\int_{0}^{3}\sqrt{1 + x}\, dx=\frac{14}{3}\) completing the question.
hints_html:
The formula for the arc length of this curve on the interval from \(0 \leq x \leq 3\) is

\(\int_{0}^{3}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx.\)
hints_latex:
The formula for the arc length of this curve on the interval from
$0 \leq x \leq 3$ is

$\int_{0}^{3}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx.$
hints_raw:
The formula for the arc length of this curve on the interval from <math> 0 \leq x \leq 3 </math> is 

<math>
\int_{0}^{3}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx.
</math>
question: 2 (c)
sols_html:
We first compute the derivative of \(y = (2/3)x^{3/2}\) and see that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = \sqrt{x}\end{aligned}\]

Plugging this into the arc length formula gives

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{3}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx = \int_{0}^{3} \sqrt{1 + \sqrt{x}^{2}}\,dx = \int_{0}^{3}\sqrt{1 + x}\, dx\end{aligned}\]

Now, let \(u = 1+x\) so that \(du = dx\) and \(u(0) = 1\) and \(u(3) = 4\). Then

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{3}\sqrt{1 + x}\, dx &= \int_{1}^{4}\sqrt{u}\, du \\ &= \left.\frac{2u^{3/2}}{3}\right|_{1}^{4} \\ &= \frac{2}{3} \left(4^{3/2} - 1 \right) \\ &= \frac{2}{3} \left(8-1 \right) \\ &= \frac{14}{3}\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
sols_raw:
We first compute the derivative of <math> y = (2/3)x^{3/2} </math> and see that

:<math> \displaystyle
\frac{dy}{dx} = \sqrt{x}
</math>

Plugging this into the arc length formula gives

:<math>
\int_{0}^{3}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx = \int_{0}^{3} \sqrt{1 + \sqrt{x}^{2}}\,dx = \int_{0}^{3}\sqrt{1 + x}\, dx
</math>

Now, let <math> u = 1+x </math> so that <math> du = dx </math> and <math> u(0) = 1 </math> and <math> u(3) = 4 </math>. Then

:<math>
\begin{align}
\int_{0}^{3}\sqrt{1 + x}\, dx &= \int_{1}^{4}\sqrt{u}\, du \\
&= \left.\frac{2u^{3/2}}{3}\right|_{1}^{4} \\
&= \frac{2}{3} \left(4^{3/2} - 1 \right) \\
&= \frac{2}{3} \left(8-1 \right) \\
&= \frac{14}{3}
\end{align}
</math>

completing the question.
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. Justify your answers and show all your work.

Determine the length of the curve \(y = (2/3)x^{3/2}\) on \(0 \leq x \leq 3\). Evaluate and completely simplify your answer.
